node.text:
Why this topic? Why now? 
 
The recent pandemic has put the human cardiovascular system in its crosshairs.  Our fear of a virus that affects the neurovascular system has inspired us to genetically engineer humanity to produce a neurovascular toxin – the Spike Protein – of CV origin.  What are the ramifications of a medical belief system and public intervention of this magnitude?  We will explore the fear-driven origins of these actions, and the biologic consequences of this direct genetic engineering experiment this Thursday, July 29 at 12 PM PT / 3 PM ET. Link in bio @zachbushmd to register.
 
The heart is the organ of passion — the key to understanding life. 
 
On our journey through life, we often talk about following our hearts, doing things that bring joy & spreading love to those around us.
 
Today, we see science racing to fight death, allowing us more time to follow our hearts and continue through this journey of life. In medicine, we do this by identifying risk factors — things that can cause disease & ultimately death. It should follow then that there be a cause-and-effect relationship between a risk factor and a disease. A common example is the risk factor of elevated cholesterol & the development of vascular (heart) disease. 
 
In 1985, Nobel Award winners Michael Brown and Joseph Goldstein said “The more LDL [cholesterol] there is in the blood, the more rapidly atherosclerosis develops.” With that, this correlation was mistaken for causation and cholesterol became the cause of vascular disease. It’s a belief still held today despite reams of scientific understanding to the contrary.
 
For this reason, we’ll be exploring The Heart in our next live webinar, illuminating its capacity for resilience and repair, reliance on cholesterol, ramifications of statin drugs and neo-vaccines, and innate function as the drumbeat of life. 
 
Few other topics in science are more relevant today. Uplevel your understanding of the vascular system, while inviting love and wisdom into your heart.
 
Link to register for this free event is in my bio @zachbushmd
 
 
.
.
.
#humanhealth #bethechange #allofustogether #newparadigm #heart #heal #thefutureisnow

node.title: Registration Now OPEN // The Heart: Understanding the Vascular System

node.text:
Registration is NOW OPEN. 

Join me, @petercummingsmd and @kwilleumier next Wednesday, June 9 at 12 PM PT / 3 PM ET for a free LIVE Webinar on The Brain: An exploration of the neuroscience of stress, fear, rest and peace.
 
In our last webinar, we discussed the rapid increase of toxic herbicides in our global food system. From the advent of genetically engineered corn in the 1990s, to the direct genetic engineering of humanity through the vaccination program, our chemical industry and regulatory agencies have aligned to place human biology in a precarious state. 

The implications for human health, disease, infertility, and extinction can generate feelings of anxiety, creating a downstream physiologic stress response. This is counterproductive for the forward movement of human ingenuity and consciousness. 

I’ve heard from so many people struggling to live their best lives given the current state of the world. We often feel helpless and alone, forgetting these feelings are not representative of the reality we actually live in. Instead, they are the result of how our brains interpret the world around us. 

We tend to view the brain as an organ that controls everything we do, not realizing we are actually in control. Understanding more about how the brain creates stress and anxiety can help us find strategies to manage our emotional responses. In turn, we can learn to control our thoughts, actions, and intentions — thus controlling our emotions and responses to any event in our lives. 

In a step forward together, we are focusing our next installment of the Global Health Education initiative on the human brain, diving into the neuroscience of stress and release, while giving actionable strategies to live a more healthy, balanced life with less fear and more creativity. 

Through a deeper understanding of who we are and where we came from, we can return to a cooperative, constructive, and co-creative member of this web of life.

*Link to register & learn more is in my bio @zachbushmd. Replay will be shared after the event to anyone who registers.

node.title: LIVE Webinar & NEW blog post on The Brain

node.text:
It’s been a year of seclusion, we need to recover community & immunity through hugs.

Studies have shown more than five hugs a day reduces the risk of viral respiratory illness by more than 30% 

It's time to share our tables with one another again. 

Welcoming someone with a warm embrace delivers a dopamine surge directly to the brain — the same rush we experience from the fat-salt-sugar combination of comfort food, but with real health benefits. 

At 15-30 seconds into a hug, we experience a massive serotonin dopamine download, bringing a rush of joy & love that surges throughout the body. Not only will a hug positively affect your mood & relationship it will also boost your innate immunity which keeps you in healthy relationship to the 10 million different viruses in your blood stream. 

Through a hug we can be fulfilled by much more than the content of the plate. 

Similarly, have you ever noticed a particular person who draws others toward them? Our bodies are subconsciously drawn toward the light energy that radiates from a joyful person — it’s our innate desire to feel & receive love. Just as the palms of two hands interlock perfectly, the body was designed to embrace one another through outstretched arms & an open heart. 

Contrasted with someone else who walks into the same room without even being noticed, the difference is palpable. When someone’s energy falls to a lower vibration, we can feel weakness & become less drawn to touch.

The sad reality is, as soon as disorder sets in, the response of others is to shift away from touch. As isolation increases, we become compelled to stay in bed & isolate. In isolation, our mental, physical & immune health diminish.

Instead of being repelled when someone is in a weakened state, our greatest healing power is to recognize a weakening human light & respond with connection. 

We must reconnect to the soul's instinct to scoop one another up & stoke that flame of life with a good hug & sincere look in the eye that says: I see you. I'm glad you're here. I'm blessed to share this space with you. 

Reconnect humanity, reconnect.

.
.

full interview with @that.health.chick at link in my bio @zachbushmd

node.title: When was the last time you started a meal with a hug?

node.text:
Maria Catalán is her name.
The land she stewards is her legacy.
She is the first Latina farm worker turned farm owner.

Maria is an organic farmer and activist fighting for migrant worker’s rights and the development of an equitable food system where access to fresh produce should be a right, not a privilege.

The more we intertwine our lives with the lives of those who tend to the food on which we are all dependent, the more we become connected to the great honor it is to support them.

If you are inspired to do an act of giving today, let it be to support Maria Catalán and her efforts. Link in bio @zachbushmd

.
.
.

Read the full feature @farmersfootprint 
🎥  @leia_vita

node.text:
I am blessed to be joined today by my wife Jenn Perell Bush on this Instagram live as we dive into the topics of change and choice, which is the title of Jenn's new course that is available to the public. Engage in self exploration with the resources and toolbox that Jenn has created, or bring together a group of friends and colleagues to engage as a community for change. 

We are at the tipping point of humanity, and for life on Earth.  We simply have to change everything.  Let's get engaged. Let's choose the future that we want for our future humanity.

Learn more at JennPerellBush.com

node.text:
We’ve built an entire economy around the concept of healthcare.  This economy is now the largest industry in America, more than four times larger than the military industrial complex. 

Our population today is being subconsciously controlled by our food systems, begging the question of whether our food delivers health or not.  The population health statistics would suggest not.  We rank 35th in the world in health outcomes and experienced more than 20% of Covid-related deaths in the world (with only 4%of the world's population in the US). 

In my first appearance on the Rich Roll podcast back in 2018, @richroll and I journeyed deep into our increasingly toxic food systems, diving into the history of chemical farming and its direct impact on the loss of human health. This episode became one of the most popular conversations in the history of the show, not to mention one of my most cherished conversations of all time.

Since then, I often receive messages from members of this community who deeply resonate with this story, yet struggle articulating the complexity and detail back to their friends and family. Today, I am honored to unveil this collaboration with my extremely talented and generous friend Mark Wooding at @AfterSkool100 , who took the time and energy to simplify this expansive message down to this beautifully visual format. 

As we approach the end of Earth Month, I encourage you to watch and share this video with your friends, family, neighbors, and the rest of your online network. By tapping into the power of this community, we can create a ripple effect that educates and inspires the rest of humanity to become conscious and awake. 

Please help me in sharing this message so we can collectively change our mindset and move into alignment with Mother Nature.

#chemicalfarming #regenerativefuture #humanhealth #soilhealth #afterskool

node.title: Chemical Farming & The Loss of Human Health

node.text:
Dr McGarey just began her second century of life. Born in 1920 in India to two American parents, they began their medical journey as 2 osteopathic physicians in rural North India in 1916. 

Your mind will be blown and soul enlightened as she details through the arc of her hundred years of health and healing, beginning in the rural tent villages with her parents that eventually lead to her own career as a pioneering physician. 

Gladys began medical school in 1941, and 80 years later, she continues to see clients today in her health coaching practice.

In the last few weeks, her mind opened even further to revolutionary new ideas about the trajectory of health and humanity in the coming century. Listen as she details her profound new philosophy on Living Medicine, grounded in the foundation of the five Ls:

* Life: Life by itself is like a seed that’s sitting on the ground, with all the energy of the universe within it. That seed can sit idle for eons until the spark of….
* Love: The divine essence that activates life, loves grows through the beauty of the sun, rain, and the soil.
* Laughter: Without love, laughter is cruel. But combined with love, laughter is warm, joyous, and happy. 
* Labor: Labor without love is drudgery, but labor with love is bliss. It’s why the singers sing, why the painters paint, why doctors become doctors — it’s what makes your heart sing.
* Listening: Without love, listening is empty sound. But listening with love is understanding, which is the very foundation of Living Medicine. 

If you are giving up hope on humanity, be inspired and renewed in this conversation with an extraordinary woman and visionary. Don’t miss this discussion with @begladmd.
.
.
.

#awakening #humanhealth #allofustogether #newparadigm #futurist #zachbushmd

node.title: The Grandmother of Humanity: Gladys McGarey MD

node.text:
Why aren’t we taught to observe nature?

From a very early age, our current educational experience takes us away from observational and experiential learning. We are separated by screens, text books, and whiteboards from the world that we live in. Learning is abstract for the vast majority of industrialized civilization.  We are taught to memorize the common narrative and structure of the current dominant paradigm.
 
In Western society, our children are taught to memorize periodic tables, abstract geography, language, and history from books. It has been more than a century since our children routinely sat at the feet of their elders, listening to their stories and wisdom at the fireside. We do not know where we have come from, what efforts and challenges our previous generations have forged through.  We do not understand where our food comes from.  

Our children are not given responsibility at young ages to participate in the mission of community.  We grow into adulthood in these abstract environments to further memorize the dominant norms for our social behaviors, eating habits, daily routines, our jobs, even our relationship roles and behaviors. Imagine if we moved from abstract knowledge and beliefs to engaged learning and co-creation?

Our First Nations people continue to strive to preserve not just their culture, but our collective humanity. Imagine if every kindergarten course began with listening to the chant of a local tribe, starting each day within the vibration of sound from tens of thousands of years ago, taught by generation after generation after generation. Each child could then learn their own Indigenous roots that reach back to largely extinct Indegnous peoples and cultures.  My Nordic and Mediterranean roots have long run dry, but there is a pulse within me, an ancient memory of the languages, songs, and stories that raised my potential for knowingness.  Experiencing Indigenous peoples and cultures reignites this pulse and memory within me....

CONTINUED ON THE NEXT POST

node.text:
Now open for registration.

Join me for a free LIVE Webinar and Q&A next Tuesday, March 30 at 12 PM PT / 3 PM ET where we ask the question, what are we really afraid of when it comes to death? 

I believe the answer is rooted in the fearful definition we coined for nature: “The phenomena of the physical world collectively, including plants, animals, the landscape, and other features and products of the earth, as opposed to humans or human creations.” [Oxford English Dictionary]

Not only did we write ourselves out of the definition of nature, we put ourselves in opposition to it. 

As we separate ourselves from nature, we become prone to a fundamental fear of scarcity. We are afraid that we do not have enough: Not enough time, not enough sleep, not enough food, not enough stuff, not enough fun, not enough love… 

But, deeper than this, you come to fear that YOU are not enough. In this mentality of scarcity, we come to fear death. What if we do not live enough? What if we do not leave our mark, our legacy, our knowledge, our memory… 

We are afraid of the ending of self. 

Yet science, spiritual teachings, and human experience over the millenia are all in agreement: There is no end to the energy that animates you to the life you experience today. Energy cannot be destroyed — it is a fundamental law of the physical reality of our universe. As such, there is no such thing as death as it is commonly conceived.

This month in our Global Health Education event, we’ll explore the topic of Death, Dying & Rebirth. Join me, Dr Guy Danielson, Dr Peter Cummings, death doula Michelle Renee and Hospice Nurse Gabrielle Jimenez as we expand your thinking and open your eyes to the resources available so you can proactively establish your own philosophy on death. Whether you or a loved one are approaching the end of this life, it’s important to understand the types of support you can have around as you journey toward a rebirth. 

We have the opportunity to reframe death, to let go of the fear, and learn to live differently in that newfound freedom.
 
Please share & join us. Link to register is in my bio @zachbushmd

node.title: LIVE Webinar & NEW Knowledge Base Release on Death, Dying, & Rebirth

node.text:
We have heard about millions of cases of a viral infection, we have heard about 400,000 US deaths, and the new administration has created beautiful imagery to remember those lost, but at no point have we been given context for these devastating statistics.
 
Consider this.

Each year 250,000 people in the US die from medical errors.  Not side effects of medications or drugs, but from mistakes that we make as doctors.  We wield a dangerous tool box.  In the course of the the Obama/Biden administration 2 million died of medical errors.  Another 1 million during the Trump administration.  No economies were shut down. No military state was called for.
 
Each year 750,000 children die of pneumonia in Sub-Saharan Africa alone.  Every year.  There is no global response.  Instead Western and Eastern governments and corporations continue take the opportunity to exploit the peoples and resources of these suffering nations. 
 
Every year 1.8 million people die of lung cancer.  The planes keep flying, the refineries keep burning, the herbicide spraying continues.
 
It is time for us to look at what happened, and what is the context of the numbers and the science of our reality. 
 
If we yearn to honor the lives lost this year, we must endeavor to see the reality of our collective actions, vulnerabilities, and the opportunities we have for change.
 
If you missed it last week, catch the release of the recording of the Global Health Education Summit – What Happened Last Year. Link in bio @zachbushmd

Let’s now join together to reimagine our future and rewrite humankind back into the definition of nature. I would be honored if you would share this video replay with at least one friend or family member, so we can reach that future even faster.
.
.
.
.
#humanhealth #globalhealtheducation #microbiome #bethechange #newparadigm #healtheducation #thefutureisnow #zachbushmd

node.text:
During WWII, 40% of our food was grown in our own backyards. 

Back then, we called these Victory Gardens, grounded in the belief that our independence would come from our resilience. 

Though life for many at this time was unimaginably difficult, we looked to homegrown food as a source of independence, freedom, and health. In many ways, WWII became a war of attrition through resources, and the secret was not through better technology or better railroads, but through decentralization and backyard gardens. 

For the first time since the 1940s, this past year led thousands of families to plant their own backyard gardens. Despite all the pandemonium we've created as a population, we still bought nearly every last seed available in the US. 

Once we started growing, it didn't take long to realize that seeds have all the magic. We’ve started to learn that if you create anything besides a lawn in your backyard, you're winning the game for the planet and for your own independence. And the less we metal in the garden, the more beauty will come out of it. 

Farmers are always the first to say that the more you try to fight Mother Nature, the more you're going to lose. In my experience working with farmers and families through @farmersfootprint, I find the most successful farmers are always making space for nature to do the work. 

Whether you’ve got a multi-acre farm or aspirations for your own small backyard garden, I encourage you to find the magic in the seeds and let Mother Nature do her work. Just by connecting with some soil and water, you'll tap into the biophotonic energy around us and channel that into a healing power within you. 

Follow @farmersfootprint to stay connected to regenerative principles, foodways and farmers and don’t miss the rest of this conversation with @trent_sd — link is in my bio @zachbushmd
.
.
.

#thefutureisnow #humanhealth #bethechange #allofustogether #newparadigm #soilhealth #regenerativeag #futurist #zachbushmd

node.text:
In 1965, 4% of the population had a chronic disease. Today in the US alone, 52% of our children have at least one. Research from around the world suggests that environmental factors are the main contributors to this collapse of human health.

Over the last 40 years, we have destroyed more than half of all biology on the planet. Chemical fertilizers, herbicides, and pesticides have wiped out 97% of agriculture soils on Earth, decimating the biodiversity within nature that’s paramount to our survival. 

We are being called to understand the importance of biodiversity and its direct impact on the health of our planet and species. By learning to work within a co-creative process with Mother Nature, we can witness richer soils and more abundance of health than ever seen before. 

Around the world, brands and business leaders are also being called to answer: How is your economic and social decision-making beneficial to the planet and every human life your business and supply chain touches?

Brands like @sambazon, @guayaki, and @drbronner are at the forefront of this conversation, creating templates of how to work with Mother Nature instead of against her. By building sustainable business models that regenerate our ecosystems and communities, they’re able to create socially responsible practices that reverse climate change and help combat poverty, racism, malnutrition, and inequality. 

Stay tuned for the premiere of @seedingchangefilm on April 22, 2021 — a new film all about the power of conscious commerce. 

Until then, be a part of the solution and take action. Challenge your concept of business and social consciousness as separate forces and see how they work together in harmony while looking intently at the food and product brands you are supporting. Behind any one product or vegetable there is an origin story worth knowing for your own health.. 

You can sign up today @seedingchangefilm to gain full access to the film when it releases.
.
.
.

#regenerativeagriculture #seedingchangefilm #thefutureisnow #bethechange #newparadigm #zachbushmd

node.text:
Cholesterol is vital to your health and daily life.

Despite common misbeliefs and perceptions, cholesterol is a cornerstone to your resiliency and regenerative capacity. 

Among an array of critical roles, it is the foundation of our innate immune system, our vascular and neural cell walls, and many steroid hormones like estrogen, testosterone, and vitamin D. 

Interestingly, cholesterol intake from food has little, if any, effect on concentrations in the blood. Most of the cholesterol we eat is attached to an alcohol group called esterified cholesterol, which is poorly absorbed. As such, only about 20% of the cholesterol in our blood comes from the food we eat, while 80% is produced by our liver. 

It was originally thought that the higher your LDL cholesterol, the greater your risk of developing heart disease. In this theory, heart attacks and strokes result from excess LDL that becomes trapped in the walls of arteries, initiating an inflammatory reaction that causes the arteries to narrow. 

Yet through numerous studies, it’s been well established that there is no relationship between the level of cholesterol and the severity of atherosclerosis detected by autopsy. 

So then why does high cholesterol often predict cardiovascular disease? 

High cholesterol levels may be secondary to other disease-promoting environmental factors: Lack of physical activity, smoking, obesity, poor diet, loss of sleep, and mental stress. These are all associated with chronic systemic inflammation and may be an epiphenomenal sign that something else is wrong. Living in a state of chronic inflammation alters the ability of our arteries to keep cholesterol out of the vessel walls, while making it toxic to the body.

Interested in learning more? Join us for a live webinar as we explore The Heart this Thursday, July 29 at 12pm PT / 3pm ET. We’ll illuminate the heart’s capacity for resilience and repair, discussing strategies to manage your cholesterol and improve your overall heart health. I look forward to seeing you there. 

*Link to register & learn more is in my bio @zachbushmd. 

.

.

.

#heart #hearthealth #vasculardisease #thefutureisnow

node.text:
Why this topic? Why now? 
 
The recent pandemic has put the human cardiovascular system in its crosshairs.  Our fear of a virus that affects the neurovascular system has inspired us to genetically engineer humanity to produce a neurovascular toxin – the Spike Protein – of CV origin.  What are the ramifications of a medical belief system and public intervention of this magnitude?  We will explore the fear-driven origins of these actions, and the biologic consequences of this direct genetic engineering experiment this Thursday, July 29 at 12 PM PT / 3 PM ET. Link in bio @zachbushmd to register.
 
The heart is the organ of passion — the key to understanding life. 
 
On our journey through life, we often talk about following our hearts, doing things that bring joy & spreading love to those around us.
 
Today, we see science racing to fight death, allowing us more time to follow our hearts and continue through this journey of life. In medicine, we do this by identifying risk factors — things that can cause disease & ultimately death. It should follow then that there be a cause-and-effect relationship between a risk factor and a disease. A common example is the risk factor of elevated cholesterol & the development of vascular (heart) disease. 
 
In 1985, Nobel Award winners Michael Brown and Joseph Goldstein said “The more LDL [cholesterol] there is in the blood, the more rapidly atherosclerosis develops.” With that, this correlation was mistaken for causation and cholesterol became the cause of vascular disease. It’s a belief still held today despite reams of scientific understanding to the contrary.
 
For this reason, we’ll be exploring The Heart in our next live webinar, illuminating its capacity for resilience and repair, reliance on cholesterol, ramifications of statin drugs and neo-vaccines, and innate function as the drumbeat of life. 
 
Few other topics in science are more relevant today. Uplevel your understanding of the vascular system, while inviting love and wisdom into your heart.
 
Link to register for this free event is in my bio @zachbushmd
 
 
.
.
.
#humanhealth #bethechange #allofustogether #newparadigm #heart #heal #thefutureisnow

node.text:
The microbiome has become a buzzword in today’s consumer lexicon. 

From women's health journals to bar soap, nearly every product and publication has begun to tout its connection with the microbiome. And rightfully so: it’s essential for human life, fueling our development, immunity, and nutrition. 

Today, we understand the microbiome enables our production of energy, micronutrients, & regenerative pathways. It manufactures the neurotransmitters that support our short term memory, our mood stability, sleep quality, sexual function, stress hormones, dopamine, and more — all of which are produced at the gut lining. 

As human beings, our neurologic capacity begins with our connection to the microbiome. At its most basic definition, micro means small, & biome signifies living creatures — essentially all of the living microbes on & inside the human body. 

Interestingly, after decades of genomics research, it has become apparent that human cells are not at the center of human health, but rather it's the fungi and bacteria that are. It is estimated that we have 50 to 70 trillion human cells, which pale in comparison to the 1.4 quadrillion bacteria, 10 quadrillion fungi, & 14 quadrillion mitochondria inside our bodies. In fact, the number of genes in one person’s microbiome is 200X the number of genes in the entire human genome. 

As we explore the microbiome and our human biology, it's clear this diverse non-human micro ecosystem is what makes life possible. Within every organ system throughout our whole body, it’s this unique niche of bacteria, fungi, & yeast that nurture our human cells.

Even long before we humans showed up, it was the microscopic creatures within the microbiome that developed life on Earth. Since then, this planet has shown itself to be passionate about one thing: biodiversity — with the microbiome continuously trying to diversify life, finding more and more adaptation at every opportunity. 

In celebration of World Microbiome Day, let's get out in it today! Kick off the shoes, walk in a garden, on a forest path, a beach, a meadow, or mountain top.  Extra credit for all of the above.... 

artwork: hand and laster cut microbes by @rogan_brown_

node.text:
Seeds are the foundation for our relationship with the Earth and with each other. 

Not only do they produce food, but they also create foodways, including cultural customs of food production, preservation, preparation, presentation, and gathering. Additionally, research suggests that ancient seeds from traditional agricultural varieties can help solve food shortages and malnutrition, while boosting food system resilience to climate and cultural challenges.

Yet today, we face significant issues with seed sovereignty. Companies around the world are working toward making indigenous seeds illegal, creating laws that strip farmers of their right to use their own seeds and force them to purchase corporatized seeds. 

In Africa specifically, corporations are blocking farmers from being able to save, sell, and exchange their seeds. These policies threaten to erase entire seed varieties, foodways, and cultures that have relied on saved seeds for millennia.

Indigenous seeds are closely linked to a healthy microbiome and the power they hold should be in the hands of the people who steward these seeds.

The microbiome of indigenous seeds is characterized by a high diversity and abundance of bacteria, archaea, and fungi, with up to 20,000 microbial species and up to 2 billions bacterial cells in a single seed. 

We know our species in particular thrives on an intelligent variety of bacteria, fungi, and other microorganisms, and these ancient seeds are an optimal source to help us achieve that essential diversity.

I am honored to amplify organizations like A Growing Culture and the Alliance for Food Sovereignty in Africa — incredible groups fighting to reclaim the power of seed, and to keep these indigenous seeds in the hands of the many, not the few.

Join @agrowingculture and host @afsafrica on June 26 at 8am EDT for an exclusive event called Seed Is Power, a day-long rally in honor of the African seed. Hear from those on the frontlines of the fight to reclaim seed sovereignty and offer your support for this crucial mission. 

Link to register is in my bio @zachbushmd
.
.
.
#farmersrights #regenerativeag #humanhealth #thefutureisnow #zachbushmd

node.text:
Happy Father's Day, Dad! 

You have been an amazing cheerleader & co-creator in my life, giving me a passion for productivity & creativity. Your enthusiasm in all my paths & projects has been invaluable, spending hours playing music with me, camping & hiking, hiding under cars & in the crawlspaces of houses we have built.  Thank you for always being there, so eager to support & so full of joy.

My own path as a father has been the most amazing, humbling journey of all. Yet I often have concerns whether I'm doing enough, inspiring my kids, or being a good dad.

Now my kids are all grown up, & while they may not think about me regularly, I often wonder whether I reach out to them enough or have given them enough room to be themselves. Even when I do, I’m not really sure I know how to support them. It is a mysterious & beautiful journey for all the insecurities & worries it can trigger.

Why does the world have us build these self-expectations that allow us to sense failure even when we are successful? 

Only after 20+ years of parenthood, I’ve realized my children are here on purpose & on their own journey. My job as a father is to celebrate their journey & be witness to it, not to create their dream for them. My dream is my own to create. 

As adults, these kids are still blooming. They are beautiful.  What a relief to find out there's nothing I could do to perfect their beauty any more than it already is. I am not the source of their beauty. I am the witness to it. 

Today, I’m reminding myself & all you dads to surrender your expectations of what you think it means to be a great dad, & instead be a great person — to your family, your friends, & most importantly, you.

Ask yourself: How am I showing up? How can I be the best version of myself? How can I celebrate myself?

Challenge yourself to show up completely as your unique self so that you reflect the beauty of your children back at them. Surrender any title or complicit role that society has given you & instead live life to the fullest, highest vibration. Tap into mother nature & express the vitality of life & beauty that can flow through you today. 

To all you kids & dads out there, Happy Father’s Day.

node.text:
At what point did we relinquish our autonomy to chemical companies?
 
In medical school, we are taught patients are too lazy to get healthy, too lazy to exercise, and too lazy to change their diet. 
 
It’s so drilled into us as med students that we learn to accept the pharmaceutical approach as the only toolbox that would work.
 
Today, there is a pill for everything. Our burgeoning field of drug interventions covers everything from blood pressure and cholesterol to major depression and anxiety disorders. 
 
What I have seen to be true in my patients and this community is people don’t want a codependent relationship with the pharmaceutical industry.
 
Since starting my clinic @mclinicva in 2010, I have learned firsthand from thousands of patients that humanity wants to be well. The average person would love to exercise and eat healthy, but they lack the guidance to even get started — especially when they search online for answers. 
 
They’re not lazy, they’re overwhelmed. 
 
And it’s no wonder why. From pharmaceuticals to food systems, nearly every company in these industries has been taken over by chemical companies who cut their teeth in warfare — with today’s consumer on the other side of the battlefield.
 
But turns out, there's an exciting reality behind the curtains. The new leadership behind today’s multinational corporation is not the same as 50 years ago. They understand the importance of pivoting — they know that in the end, it’s the American consumer who stands to win the battle.
 
No matter how big an enterprise may look, ultimately the largest corporation that's ever been created is the American consumer. We consume more than anyone, anywhere in the world, influencing every single corporation and economy. 
 
The real power lies in our hands. If we demand regenerative supply chains, natural remedies, and clear labeling, this new wave of leaders will be forced to pivot to avoid losing their foothold. 
 
Autonomy is ours to reclaim.
 
If you need a team around you to create the health and future that you want, our Biology Basecamp offers 4 and 8 week programs with group or one on one coaching to get you on your highest path. Link in bio @zachbushmd

node.text:
Live Webinar TODAY: 12 PM PT / 3 PM ET - The Brain: An exploration of the neuroscience of stress, fear, rest and peace.

We’ll explore the human brain — one of the most mysterious and exquisite organs, capable of creating the incomprehensible.

Composed of billions of neurons, the brain enables the creation of extraordinary creativity, like a symphony or a piece of artwork. Just like a desktop computer, this CPU chip is not capable of generating information or ideas on its own. It instead organizes peripheral sensory experiences into patterns of behavior which we will dive into today and so much more.

I hope you feel inspired to create space in your day to join me, Dr. Peter Cummings @petercummingsmd, and Dr. Kristen Willeumier @kwilleumier TODAY at 12pm PT / 3pm ET for an exploration into the brain.

We’ll discuss the neuroscience of stress and release, offering actionable strategies to live a more healthy, balanced life with less fear and more creativity.

*Event is completely free. Link to register & learn more in my bio @zachbushmd. Replay will be shared after the event to anyone who registers. See you soon!

.
.
.
#brain #brainstorming #bethechange #thefutureisnow #zachbushmd

node.text:
In the last year, mainstream media, social media, governments, and massive corporations have created one of the biggest fear events in human history.

It is time for us to find pathways out of the fear and that is exactly what we’ll be talking about tomorrow (link in bio @zachbushmd to register)
 
The role of the vagus nerve in maintaining health and wellbeing cannot be overstated. 

Within the involuntary motor system are the sympathetic (SNS) and parasympathetic (PSNS) nervous systems. The SNS is fueled by adrenaline — the fight or flight response the body generates to perceived threats. The PSNS is the opposite, counterbalancing that response by promoting relaxation. 

The main regulator of the PSNS is the vagus nerve — the 10th cranial nerve. Originating from the brainstem, it travels all over the body after it exits the skull. In fact, Vagus means The Wanderer. 

It helps counterbalance the effects of the SNS by reducing heart and breathing rates. 
It signals for the release of prolactin, vasopressin, and oxytocin, all of which induce relaxation. 
It assists in memory foundation, facilitates deep sleep, and reduces inflammation in our gut microbiome. 

At the other extreme is the Reticular Activating System (RAS), a network of nerve connections in the brainstem. Everything we become aware of enters our awareness by passing through the RAS — it’s our danger radar that sifts through the background noise of life to detect threats. 

Interpreting the world with the RAS poses a multitude of problems in our daily lives, creating unwanted stress and fear. In such a state, we cling to the past and beat ourselves up over our mistakes. Fear also drives us to obsess about the future and worry about things that haven’t even happened. In doing so, we place importance on past or future events at the expense of the present, which is where the true value of life resides. 

Join me, @petercummingsmd , and @kwilleumier TOMORROW, JUNE 9 at 12pm PT / 3pm ET  for an exploration into the brain and discussion of strategies you can use to activate the PSNS, release your mind from the RAS, and start living the Vagus Life.

node.text:
Registration is NOW OPEN. 

Join me, @petercummingsmd and @kwilleumier next Wednesday, June 9 at 12 PM PT / 3 PM ET for a free LIVE Webinar on The Brain: An exploration of the neuroscience of stress, fear, rest and peace.
 
In our last webinar, we discussed the rapid increase of toxic herbicides in our global food system. From the advent of genetically engineered corn in the 1990s, to the direct genetic engineering of humanity through the vaccination program, our chemical industry and regulatory agencies have aligned to place human biology in a precarious state. 

The implications for human health, disease, infertility, and extinction can generate feelings of anxiety, creating a downstream physiologic stress response. This is counterproductive for the forward movement of human ingenuity and consciousness. 

I’ve heard from so many people struggling to live their best lives given the current state of the world. We often feel helpless and alone, forgetting these feelings are not representative of the reality we actually live in. Instead, they are the result of how our brains interpret the world around us. 

We tend to view the brain as an organ that controls everything we do, not realizing we are actually in control. Understanding more about how the brain creates stress and anxiety can help us find strategies to manage our emotional responses. In turn, we can learn to control our thoughts, actions, and intentions — thus controlling our emotions and responses to any event in our lives. 

In a step forward together, we are focusing our next installment of the Global Health Education initiative on the human brain, diving into the neuroscience of stress and release, while giving actionable strategies to live a more healthy, balanced life with less fear and more creativity. 

Through a deeper understanding of who we are and where we came from, we can return to a cooperative, constructive, and co-creative member of this web of life.

*Link to register & learn more is in my bio @zachbushmd. Replay will be shared after the event to anyone who registers.

node.text:
There is a network of information that streams through life within and around us. 

Trees are one of the most beautiful examples of this network, incredibly able to thrive in dying soil. They do so by communicating not only with one another, but with the other species around them that are able to produce the nutrients they need. 

This magic happens through the phenomenon of quorum sensing. 

When quorum sensing is reached, a threshold of a population is passed and hyper intelligence becomes the norm. In this true synergistic development, an entire population becomes greater than any sum of its parts. 

Which leads me to wonder: What would happen when we start quorum sensing as mammals? What would happen if humans would communicate more clearly through our thought processes? 

Through quorum sensing, I believe we could all see that we are not each unique in consciousness. 

To reach this level, we're going to have to quiet our human minds long enough to listen to the nature that we are within. If we continue to let our distracting thoughts prevail, we’ll continue believing we are the ultimate beings who deserve to control life around us. 

But if we can humble ourselves long enough to simply listen, we could open our minds to the possibility that we could quorum sense — not only with the macro life around us, but the micro life within us. 

How acutely can we tune into the greater intelligence of Mother Earth? 

How deep can our roots communicate with one another? 

How can we create a new energetic flow within ourselves?

I'm encouraged to find out. 

If we could maintain a humble listening status as a species, where we stop telling the world what we see and start listening to what she sees, we'll have the space to view ourselves differently in this web of intelligence. Through quorum sensing, we’ll get to become a hyper-conscious, hyper-intelligent player and co-creator within our greater environment.

The rest of this episode with @thehappypear is now LIVE — link in my bio @zachbushmd

node.text:
Like humans, plants suffer from isolation and lack of love. 

Projecting anger or frustration at a plant that’s within your space, or even not interacting with it, will lead to its deterioration.

It’s because nature has a way of energetically interacting with us through vibration and frequency. 

Plants emit communication through vibrations, similar to the way in which we use our voice to speak, or the way we project our emotions.   Interestingly, plants can receive vibrational information from us humans, both through the ultraviolet and infrared light that we emit, and also through the mix of vibration generated by our voice, thoughts and emotions.  

This concept of frequency and energy extends beyond plants, too. 

Crystals are critical in the way in which frequencies are interpreted out in the atmosphere, acting as energetic antenna waves that help translate vibrations into radio frequencies and digital technology. 

Thanks to crystals, DNA functions as much more than genetic information. When in contact with healthy water, DNA can form crystalline structures that receive wavelengths of light from planet and universe. This unique reception tuned by your specific DNA is thought to be linked closely with the experience of self-identity.  

It is neurologically inexplicable why we are able to wake up in the morning knowing who we are — we've never found a part of the brain capable of holding that key to self-identity. One of the more ethereal and beautiful theories of the mechanisms of self identity involves the crystal-like quality of your DNA as it arrays itself as a unique antenna.  When DNA is in its crystalline form with the 4th phase of water (a gel state of water), it acts as a tuned antenna. The result is your reception of information in the universe that’s unique to you: your self-identity. At this point we only know enough to ask more questions, and marvel at the beauty of it all.  

You are a quantum miracle, a physical manifestation born from the dance of solar radiation and light energy, water, and your unique DNA antenna.  Hello you. Thanks for showing up again today.

node.text:
It’s been a year of seclusion, we need to recover community & immunity through hugs.

Studies have shown more than five hugs a day reduces the risk of viral respiratory illness by more than 30% 

It's time to share our tables with one another again. 

Welcoming someone with a warm embrace delivers a dopamine surge directly to the brain — the same rush we experience from the fat-salt-sugar combination of comfort food, but with real health benefits. 

At 15-30 seconds into a hug, we experience a massive serotonin dopamine download, bringing a rush of joy & love that surges throughout the body. Not only will a hug positively affect your mood & relationship it will also boost your innate immunity which keeps you in healthy relationship to the 10 million different viruses in your blood stream. 

Through a hug we can be fulfilled by much more than the content of the plate. 

Similarly, have you ever noticed a particular person who draws others toward them? Our bodies are subconsciously drawn toward the light energy that radiates from a joyful person — it’s our innate desire to feel & receive love. Just as the palms of two hands interlock perfectly, the body was designed to embrace one another through outstretched arms & an open heart. 

Contrasted with someone else who walks into the same room without even being noticed, the difference is palpable. When someone’s energy falls to a lower vibration, we can feel weakness & become less drawn to touch.

The sad reality is, as soon as disorder sets in, the response of others is to shift away from touch. As isolation increases, we become compelled to stay in bed & isolate. In isolation, our mental, physical & immune health diminish.

Instead of being repelled when someone is in a weakened state, our greatest healing power is to recognize a weakening human light & respond with connection. 

We must reconnect to the soul's instinct to scoop one another up & stoke that flame of life with a good hug & sincere look in the eye that says: I see you. I'm glad you're here. I'm blessed to share this space with you. 

Reconnect humanity, reconnect.

.
.
